Comment: I have to confess that I am at loss, since I nevery play this kind of game (very usual) with white pieces. So I was improvising, trying not to fall in stupid tricks.

Even better. I make pressure on white, and force him into my game.
Even better. I make pressure on white, and force him into my game.
I can choose: NxB is ok if I want to save my own dsb, but I can also exchange it for the N in order to clear some ways.
This could have been a mistake. Now white can take NxN, and I almost lose a piece. dxN (if BxN+, NxB and I am a piece under!), BxB, exNe3, Qxe3.
My opponent chooses to free the way for his lsb to b5.
Well played, since it makes Bb5+ more dangerous.
Well played, since it makes Bb5+ more dangerous.
I saw a way to revert the possible pressure. White could have tried Nxf7, with known and uncertain results. I'll threat first.
White is forced to care for f2, and if he does properly, the game will come out even enough to be long and drawn.

Ok, now I knew I could have just trapped myself into a dead way, but I just needed one more attacker to get mate. Which is it, and which is the only right way to bring it in? Please, stop the video... :-D

I think there is nothing white can do... it was a lucky move, but I am proud of have found it, and also its elegance.
If I wanted to create such a position for a tactic excercise, I could have lost half of my life! :-) Thanks to my opp!
